topic.name: Oral Interpretation & Public Reading
topic.sub_subject_name: Art History, Aesthetic Philosophy & Christian Worldview
topic.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Oral Interpretation & Public Reading in Fine Arts

objectives.objective_text: Identify God's Word as special.
Identify who is speaking.
Identify rhyming words.
Identify a pause.
Identify the listener.
Listen when Scripture is read.
Tell a story with a beginning, middle, and end.
Read a Bible verse loud and clear.
Hold the Bible respectfully.
Summarize the meaning of the passage before reading.
Explain why we pause at periods and commas.
Emphasize the most important words.
Explain the office of the Lector.
Defend the public reading of Scripture as a central act of worship (1 Tim 4:13).
Talk as a puppet character.
Wait for the other person to finish.
Say a line with a specific feeling.
Summarize what the character is talking about.
Explain who the character is talking to.
Perform a short two-person scene.
Memorize a short speech.
Explain the 'moment before'.
Defend the choice of material for the actor's type.
Recite a nursery rhyme.
Clap the rhythm of the words.
Say a poem with a happy or sad voice.
Summarize the mood of the poem.
Explain how line breaks tell us when to pause.
Memorize a classic poem.
Use gestures to help tell the poem.
Explain the imagery.
Defend the oral tradition of poetry.
Speak slowly enough to be understood.
Use hands to show 'big' or 'small'.
Stand still when not moving on purpose.
Summarize the main point of the speech.
Explain why we emphasize certain words.
Use a 'dramatic pause'.
Control fidgeting.
Explain the power of silence.
Defend the classical canons of rhetoric (Delivery).
Use funny voices for different characters.
Make a face that matches the story.
Summarize a folk tale from memory.
Explain how to build suspense (get quiet/slow).
Use eye contact to engage the audience.
Explain the oral tradition.
Defend the power of story to shape culture.
Compare reading a list vs. reading a story.
Analyze the genre of the text (Psalm, Narrative, Epistle) to guide tone.
Interpret the emotion of the biblical character.
Connect eye contact with the congregation.
Analyze the 'Internal Monologue' (thoughts not spoken).
Interpret the arc of the speech.
Connect the monologue to the play's theme.
Analyze the meter (iambic, etc.) of the verse.
Interpret Enjambment (running on to the next line).
Connect the sound of words (alliteration) to the meaning.
Analyze the 'Rhetorical Triangle' (Ethos, Pathos, Logos) in delivery.
Interpret the rhythm of a speech.
Connect gesture to emphasis (don't over-gesture).
Analyze the narrative arc.
Interpret the audience's reaction and adjust.
Connect physical gesture to the spoken word.
Evaluate the impact of the reader's demeanor on the message.
Evaluate the truthfulness of the delivery.
Evaluate the difference between reading for sense vs. reading for sound.
Evaluate the non-verbal signals of a speaker.
Evaluate the ethics of appropriating others' stories.
Construct a prepared reading with exegetical insight.
Synthesize vocal technique with spiritual gravity.
Construct a contrasting monologue package for auditions.
Synthesize active listening in dialogue work.
Construct a performance of complex verse (e.g., Donne or Milton).
Synthesize analysis and performance in a recitation.
Construct a persuasive speech with polished delivery.
Synthesize content and delivery for maximum impact.
Create sound effects with the voice.
Construct a personal narrative for performance.
Synthesize rhetoric and performance.
